ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: discussion in class, writing a political science research paper

I developed a much greater understanding of the scholarly literature on civil-military relations, ranging from classic theories to recent empirical works, as well as broader knowledge of the ways in which CMR functions in countries across the globe. The course also helped work on paper writing skills and critical analysis and discussion of readings.
I learned a lot about how to write long-form PLSC/GLBL papers and how to easily read and process jargon-y PLSC papers that were previously incomprehensible.

I learned a ton about the topic of civil-military relations, as well as some larger themes related to comparative politics and international relations. I think this course does a fantastic job of diving really deep into a relatively niche topic, which I really enjoyed given the fact that many Yale courses can be very broad in what they cover. Additionally, I learned how to write better argumentative research papers and to read political science papers at a higher level.

I learned a lot about civil-military relations both in theory and in practice with case studies from all over the world. The first weeks provided a solid theoretical background on ideal civil-military relations in democracies and non-democracies, and then in the later weeks we focused on a different region each week and examined civil-military relations with a few case studies per region.
The relationship between civilian governments and the military; why coups, military governments, and other phenomena occur throughout the world.
Writing skills mainly

I learned about theories of civil-military relations and concepts such as military professionalism and coup-proofing. I also learned about the evolution of civil-military relations in different regions of the world. In terms of skills, this course helped me practice reading academic papers, and it helped me learn how to write a political science research paper.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. One major strength was the breadth of the material we covered. I also appreciated the number of diverse case studies, which helped us to see CMR theories in action. I also found the structure of the writing assignments (in terms of the final paper drafts that build on one another) to be quite helpful. I did think that the number of weekly reading responses could be cut down. Also, I was very interested in other students' final papers after they had been presented. I think one additional assignment could have been to review another student's paper draft.

The course was fantastically organized. Professor Lotito did a great job of making you understand exactly what to focus on as you were learning and doing the readings (through reading response questions that actually helped guide you). The syllabus and order of topics also does a really good job of bringing you into the topic of Civ-Mil Relations, helps you understand the field and background, and then has you dive into specifics for different regions. While the final assignment is long, it is broken up into component parts over the semester that are very accomplishable and was not a stressful exercise. 

There are honestly very few weaknesses in the course, though perhaps it would be nice to have slightly more chances to discuss historical civil-military relations (pre-WW2) which was never really brought up in the course. Then again, that might just be a better topic for a different class (that doesn't yet exist at Yale, sadly).

I think one of the main strengths of the course is Professor Lotito. He is an expert on the topic, and does a really great job of guiding discussion and supporting students. The course is also structured really well and has nice thematic organization, so it was always very clear what the readings were going to be about, and what specific topics we would be discussing in class. I appreciated that work on the term paper was spread out throughout the semester, which allowed us to get regular feedback on our progress, and also alleviated some of the work towards the end of the semester. I think one potential weakness is that the course topic is very niche, and sometimes I felt like material got redundant at times, especially in the middle of the semester before we started case studies. I think the first half of the course could potentially be shortened so that we could have more time for case studies, which I found to be some of the most interesting parts of the course.

The class was really well structured and and Professor Lotito was also great -- he was very accommodating (modified readings to make it easier on us, dropping the lowest reading responses, was very flexible with extensions). I also liked how the final was structured -- although it was 15 pages, there were smaller deadlines scattered throughout the semester so by the time the final approached I already had practically half the paper written, had thought about sources, etc. which made it a lot less stressful. The only weakness I can think of is that there weren't a lot of opportunities to get feedback on how we were doing -- only the first reading response or two had comments, and so if we ever didn't get full marks after that point it was unclear why or how to improve. We did get feedback on the paper assignments which was helpful, though.

Would like it if office hours could also be on a different day from class. Sometimes something would be mentioned in class and I wouldnt have a question until a day later, but I would have to wait until next Wednesday for office hours (Id rather discuss things in person than try to explain over email).

The professor did a great job facilitating discussion and was helpful when approached.
I like that we worked on doing comparison tables together as a class. given the nature of the case studies, creating summary tables made sense, and also allowed me to interact with other students

Strengths: The material is very interesting, and Professor Lotito is a great teacher -- our class discussions were always very engaging. Weaknesses: I would have appreciated a bit more flexibility on the weekly reading responses. They were sometimes difficult to fit in during the weeks when other writing assignments for the course were also due.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought class participation and the quality of class discussion was quite strong especially given the virtual setting. I also appreciated the breakout rooms which allowed students to brainstorm together in small groups or pairs before sharing with the broader class.

I think the 5 minute break in the middle of the seminar was crucial to my engagement and, frankly, survival. I also liked that the seminar size was small, so that you could always talk if you wanted to and felt like you were a part of the discussion at all times. The only shame really was that we never were all able to meet and person and get to know one another.

For me, synchronous classes are always preferable, so I enjoyed that we got to meet live for this seminar. I thought Prof. Lotito did a great job of leading discussion over Zoom (which isn't always easy), and was always available for office hours. He also is great with email communication, which I felt was especially important for this virtual semester.
The professor did everything possible to offset challenges by the COVID pandemic. Asking discussion questions in class was successful in getting students to participate.
Breakout rooms are great!
The course went well over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, Professor Lotito is very engaging and the course material is very interesting.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to others interested in civil-military relations.

Absolutely. The class was not only covered a fantastically interesting topic, it also did so in a way that ensured you learned a lot without having to do any pointless work or feel like you were drowning in readings. The weekly response memos were actually useful in learning, and were not a major pain like I worried they might be. For a student with any interest at all in the military, military history, foreign affairs, or democratic nation-building, this is a must-take class and a pleasure to take, too.

I would absolutely recommend this course to students! Global Affairs and Political Science seminars are often very difficult to get seats in, but I think this course really was a hidden gem that I'm lucky to have stumbled upon. It covers a really fascinating and important topic that many students aren't exposed to at Yale, and I think the small class size allows great engagement with peers and with Prof. Lotito. The workload is very manageable, especially given the fact that work on the term paper is spread out across the entire semester.

I would highly recommend this course to another student, who is interested in this topic. It provides contrasting perspectives on what could be causing issues with democratic transitions. It provides an insight into the military, which is especially valuable to one looking into security studies.

I would! For a seminar, the readings were definitely manageable (and interesting), and Professor Lotito was great and facilitated discussion really well. I really came away from the class feeling like I learned a lot, but I was never particularly overwhelmed by the workload.

Honestly it depends on what theyre interested in. Social sciences may be extremely interesting to some while it may just be another subject to others. This class was pretty new to me material-wise, but I still was able to learn a lot.
Yes

Yes, this course was very interesting, and I learned a lot about the role of the military in politics, both in the US and in other countries around the world. The course was well-structured, the workload was manageable, and the material was accessible even though I knew nothing about civil-military relations coming in. Work on the research paper starts pretty early in the semester, but I appreciated that we were guided through the research process and had the chance to get feedback on our projects over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
2 hour discussion seminar, once a week.
